94f6fe9e8f4c2f6177cb923a730b1759 (03:39): ! is the unary logical not operator
39abdb11d689a9d5ce2cef2be4febca8 (03:39): ok, that makes sense
d720019c1e1dbf88f38fedb262134205 (03:40): if i == 1, then !i is equal to 0..
94f6fe9e8f4c2f6177cb923a730b1759 (03:41): perhaps, in other languges
94f6fe9e8f4c2f6177cb923a730b1759 (03:42): ! only operates on expressions that evaluate to a bool
94f6fe9e8f4c2f6177cb923a730b1759 (03:42): (can be overloaded, of course)

69e2e9b6faa43ce63a2ecee941ecc641 (04:49): ok, if you're going to call dynamic (that is, non static methods) you need an object to call them on
69e2e9b6faa43ce63a2ecee941ecc641 (04:49): you're calling a static data member
69e2e9b6faa43ce63a2ecee941ecc641 (04:50): except, it isn't marked static
69e2e9b6faa43ce63a2ecee941ecc641 (04:50): nor should it be static
69e2e9b6faa43ce63a2ecee941ecc641 (04:50): it shouldn't belong to the class
39abdb11d689a9d5ce2cef2be4febca8 (04:50): how do I change that?   (Im really new)
69e2e9b6faa43ce63a2ecee941ecc641 (04:50): so instantiate a second form, and instance.Password or whatever
69e2e9b6faa43ce63a2ecee941ecc641 (04:50): you should go read up about how classes work vs. objects
69e2e9b6faa43ce63a2ecee941ecc641 (04:50): might be useful
